data.title: Merck: Wall Street Surprised By Q3 Strength, Keytruda Sales Surge
data.description:
I will start our "journey" with a quote from The Little Prince.

It is only with the heart that one can see rightly; what is essential is invisible to the eye.

You might wonder, "why this one?" and I think it accurately describes Merck & Co., Inc. (MRK), as Mr. Market and retail investors focused all their attention on the Q3 numbers behind Keytruda and its Gardasil franchise, which, as I have said many times before, is experiencing difficulties in China's HPV vaccine market [in this article, for example].

But the main value of Merck is hidden from the public eye, and in my opinion, Keytruda Qlex, Winrevair, and Welireg will become its "cash cows," thereby lowering Wall Street's level of fear about the launch of biosimilars to pembrolizumab in 2028/2029.

Well, I'm done with the philosophical speculations.

Merck's revenue was $17.3 billion for the three months ended September 30, up 9.4% quarter-on-quarter thanks to solid performance in its Animal Health segment [$1.6 billion in Q3 2025 vs. $1.5 billion in Q3 2024] and Pharmaceuticals [$15.6 billion vs. $14.9 billion], whose sales I also marked in the plot below.

Meanwhile, Merck did not fail its investors with non-GAAP EPS, as it came in at $2.58, beating Wall Street's consensus estimate by 23 cents and even my 'best-case' scenario by 6 cents.

Now, it's time to show you 3 factors and a little bit beyond them that will explain why I consider Merck a Big Pharma cancer stock with a unique, attractive risk/reward profile.

Keytruda and Welireg are Merck's two saviors

So, I think it's logical on my part to move straight to Keytruda [pembrolizumab; checkpoint inhibitor] instead to start a conversation about other "blockbusters" or "emerging stars" in Merck's rich vaccine or cardiovascular franchises.

But this does not mean that I will not give them the opportunity to "show themselves" later, namely I will definitely mention the performance of Winrevair [treatment of pulmonary arterial hypertension], Capvaxive [pneumococcal vaccine] and Prevymis [antiviral medicine against CMV].

Since I believe the best way to begin fully uncovering Keytruda's potential, which Mr. Market doesn't see or doesn't want to price into Merck shares, not with the dry numbers behind its sales in Q3, but with its clinical data presented at ESMO Congress 2025.

At ESMO 2025, Keytruda "shined," as it has in previous years, thanks to the results of studies, such as Phase 3 KEYNOTE-775 [NCT03517449], KEYNOTE-B96 [NCT05116189], and KEYNOTE-905 [NCT03924895].

Of this "trio," I'm choosing the KEYNOTE-905 clinical trial because it assessed the efficacy of Keytruda not as monotherapy but in combination with 'gem' for oncologists called Padcev, which I often mention in articles about Pfizer (PFE), including in the last one, "Pfizer: Still a Bargain Despite Kennedy's Anti-Vaccine Attacks."

Since I can "kill 2 birds with one stone," I want to remind you right here that Padcev generated $542 million in Q2 2025, up 37.6% from $394 million in Q2 2024. Meanwhile Pfizer will publish its Q3 numbers on November 4, and I project that sales of this anti-Nectin-4 ADC will reach $610 million [that's roughly 12.5% ​​more than in the previous quarter].

Well, I am finished with that, and I will return to Keytruda+Padcev, which was used as perioperative therapy [that is, before, during, and after surgery].

On October 18, I applauded Merck/Pfizer after seeing impressive clinical data for this "duet" in the fight against MIBC [muscle-invasive bladder cancer].

I used the word 'impressive' not simply because it its primary and secondary endpoints, but more importantly, taking Merck's PD-1 inhibitor with Padcev reduced the risk of EFS events and the risk of death by 60% [95% CI: 0.28-0.57, P<0.0001] and 50% [95% CI: 0.33-0.74, P=0.0002], respectively, compared to this patients who underwent surgery alone.

But of course, I won't stop there since there is another thing directly related to KEYNOTE-905. But which one?

As reported by Merck last Thursday, October 23, the FDA granted "Priority Review" status [like I said in the article about Teva (TEVA), their decision will be made within 6 months and not 10] for 2 BLAs for Keytruda, its subcutaneous version Keytruda Qlex, and Padcev.

Moving on, I believe the U.S. regulatory agency will approve them by April 7, 2026, in part because they could help oncologists close a pretty large gap in the treatment of cisplatin-ineligible patients with MIBC.

I won't keep you waiting and will say that Keytruda has once again done what it does best, namely to be a "cash cow" for Merck. I would even call it a "magic wand."

Well, I believe that FDA approval of Keytruda, on June 13, for the treatment of resectable locally advanced HNSCC, as well as the growing demand for it from people suffering from RCC and triple-negative breast cancer in the U.S. and Japan/Europe, more than offset the competition from "heavyweights," such as BMS' Opdivo/Opdivo Qvantig (BMY) and Regeneron's Libtayo (REGN).

You might want to ask me how much this antibody that blocks the PD-1 pathway beat my base-case scenario?

And I'll tell you, with a wide margin, namely $165 million.

And yet, I want to point out is that its sales grew 2.3% quarter-on-quarter to $8.1 billion, which is perfectly visible in the graph above.

And I'll talk a little bit about Merck's oncology franchise. Keytruda is already a "red giant," but its "infant star" is Welireg, which posted $196 million in sales, up 41% year-on-year. What event helped? I think because the FDA gave it "green light" on May 14 to treat pheochromocytoma and paraganglioma.

Since I was interested to learn about this rare tumor, perhaps like you, I found an article on PubMed that said it affects 2 to 8 people per million.

Risks

I've highlighted seven key risks, including ongoing soft demand for Vaxneuvance and Janumet, in the table below.

Takeaway

Besides Keytruda and Welireg, I single out Capvaxive, Prevymis, RotaTeq, and Zerbaxa as the extra "Fantastic Four."

These 4 medications and 2 vaccines were once again confirmed my earlier assumptions that Merck's position is strengthening at high speed in 2 key therapeutic areas, such as cardiovascular and infectious.

And as a result, my final 10 words will be that I continue to cover Merck with a Strong Buy rating.

Editor's Note: This article discusses one or more securities that do not trade on a major U.S. exchange. Please be aware of the risks associated with these stocks.

data.title: The Other Side Of Ares Capital's Strong Quarter
data.description:
From early 2024 until mid September, 2025, I had a long position in Ares Capital (ARCC). My initial thesis was based on strong fundamentals, unique loan origination capabilities and diversified investment platform, which positioned ARCC well for capturing the increasing demand for private credit in a high-spread and low-risk manner.

While the total return figure was very attractive and exceeded that of BDC index (BIZD), I decided to liquidate my position before Q3 report. In fact, I went even as far as plotting a case for a likely dividend reduction, hence the title of article: Dare I Say It, Ares Capital Is About To Cut Its Dividend.

The main reason for this move was the combination of declining base rates, unfavorable exposure to spread compression dynamics, rising risks on the non-accrual front (due to large non first-lien position) and relatively thin base dividend coverage level.

Plus, the fact that Morgan Stanley Direct Lending Fund (MSDL) and Kayne Anderson BDC, Inc. (KBDC) - comparable high-quality BDCs - were trading at almost 20% cheaper P/NAV metrics made my decision much easier. Just for the context, this is why I consider MSDL and KBDC directly comparable to ARCC:

  • All three are externally managed BDCs (i.e., no reason for having premium for more cost effective internal management component).
  • All three have investment grade balance sheets.
  • None of them focuses on venture capital or lower middle market lending.
  • The net debt to equity ratios are rather similar within 1.0x to 1.25x range (usual BDC target capital structure levels); and, actually, KBDC has 0.90x, which provides an advantage in terms of funding growth via additional debt issuances.
  • Non-accruals on a FV basis are below 2.0% for all three names.
  • The portfolio company interest rate coverage ratios are at 2.0x or above (MSDL and KBDC portfolio companies have even higher than it is for ARCC - at 2.0x).
  • The base dividend coverage levels are almost identical - for ARCC it is 102% and for both MSDL and KBDC at 100%.

In other words, the rationale for exiting ARCC is similar to what I have outlined in my piece on Blackstone Secured Lending (BXSL) - i.e., too high price relative to underlying fundamentals and comparable peer valuations.

So far, my thesis has been playing out nicely actually:

However, as I have stated in the title of this article, the Q3, 2025 report for ARCC was exceptionally strong, beating the consensus expectations and, to be honest, surprising me as well.

So, let's now together dissect the key data points and determine whether ARCC has really become more attractive after the publication of Q3 financials.

Thesis update

All in all, ARCC bulls could not have asked for better results than what were delivered now. It seems that ARCC was firing on all cylinders in Q3 period, checking the necessary boxes for incremental value creation and stability across the board.

I will share the main points that we should appreciate:

  • The NAV per share increased from $19.90 in Q2 to $20.01 now with the main driver being the second highest net realized gain amount that has been achieved since ARCC's inception.
  • The weighted average spread over SOFR for the newly funded loan investments came in at 580 basis points, which implies a spread widening by about 20 basis points compared to the previous quarter.
  • Non-accruals decreased from very low base of 1.2% in Q2 to 1.0% now.
  • The underlying portfolio company credit profile improved as the TTM EBITDA continued to trend upwards.

On top of that, the management in the earnings call made it very clear to the audience that it is strongly committed to maintaining the existing dividend distribution amounts unchanged:

As a starting point, in the third quarter of 2025, our core earnings continued to exceed our dividend. Second, during the last period of rising short-term interest rates in 2022 to '23, we intentionally set our dividend at a level equivalent to a 9% to 10% ROE, which is a level we have historically achieved through different interest rate cycles over the last 20 years. We set the dividend at this level because we believe we can sustain this level of profitability through market cycles. The third point worth highlighting on this topic is what we view as our unique financial position with multiple levers to expand earnings or offset headwinds solely from falling market rates.

Plus, I know that many BDC investors like to pay attention to the undistributed spillover income, which in this case stands at $1.26 per share, representing more than 2 quarters of ARCC full dividend payments.

Hearing all of this, you might wonder how in the world one could be bearish on ARCC when basically all of the key fundamentals remain robust and/or are improving.

I will explain. There are some important details that are not so obvious. But before doing that, I would like to once again emphasize that I am not recommending shorting ARCC. Instead, my overall motivation to avoid ARCC is primarily linked to the availability of more compelling BDC risk-adjusted return alternatives in the market, such as the aforementioned KBDC and MSDL.

So, I have two conceptual items here.

First, the net investment income per share continued to decline, landing at $0.48 per share as of Q3, 2025. For me this was not a surprise because it is just inevitable that BDC portfolio yields will be going down in a lower base rate environment. So far, we have had only one 25 bps cut (and a second one right while I am writing this article), which has, by the way, only partially percolated through ARCC's books (it takes time). The portfolio-wide yield for ARCC has declined from 10.9% in Q2 to 10.6% now in Q3. Given that the consensus estimate on the near-term base rate cuts indicate a total of 75 bps reduction (at least), there is still a long way to go for ARCC to reach equilibrium portfolio yield. And here we have to understand that it is per definition that ARCC's NII per share generation will get negatively impacted.

Just to introduce more details here:

  • As per the most recent 10-Q filing, we can see that each 25 bps of a cut would translate to about $28 million of a drop in the net income or roughly 2% of the total ARCC's income result.
  • If we factor in the already made cuts this year and additional 50 bps over the course of Q4, 2025 - Q1, 2026, the combined negative impact on the income generation would be between 6% and 8% as we have to remember that the first base rate cut that occurred earlier this year has not fully percolated through the system (e.g., private credit loans usually come with 3-month SOFR reset periods).
  • On top of this, we have to add a headwind from the inflated non-accrual side, which as I will discuss below is currently below the historical average. I think that assuming a convergence to the mean (i.e., an uptick of ~1.2% in non-accrual on a FV basis). It really depends on the specific case that goes to non-accrual, but a good rule of the thumb would be a synchronized NII per share drop.
  • Finally, I have to mention the $2.15 billion of fixed rate notes that are currently outstanding with maturity dates kicking in on January, 2026 ($1.15 billion) and July, 2026 ($1 billion). Given the cost of debt that ARCC can achieve in the markets (low 5%), there is about 2.5% (on a weighted average basis) of a drag from potential refinancings. On an annualized basis this implies ~$50 million of an interest expense headwind - i.e., ~1.75% of a drop in net income.

So, by summing all of the variables together, we arrive at 8% to 10% of a near-term income reduction (by near-term I mean next 12 month period).

Now, considering that the quarterly base dividend is at $0.48 per share, it means that currently base dividend coverage is 100%. Namely, there is no margin of safety left for ARCC to cover the dividend with NII.

Second, while I fully appreciate ARCC's ability to underwrite investment at higher than average spreads that have lower than average risk, I just think that it would be only prudent that we factor in some kind of normalization (i.e., a scenario in which not everything works out perfectly as in this quarter).

For example, speaking of non-accruals, the current level of 1.0% (on FV basis) is below ARCC's historical average of around 2.2%. Sooner or later, there will be an upswing here, especially if we take into account the prevailing macro backdrop, which seems increasingly more uncertain/risky.

It is also hard to imagine how ARCC could keep recognizing almost record beating net realized gains. The only reason why in Q3 ARCC was able to hit the significant figure was the sale of Potomac Energy Center, which was previously underperforming investment, placed on a non-accrual. Potomac resulted resulted in $262 million of net realized gain. For the context, over the past four quarters (excluding Q3, 2025), the average net realized gain position was actually negative $7.25 million. Plus, it happens very rarely that an underperforming asset gets restructured and monetized at gain (not loss) - i.e., we can consider it a one-off.

Moreover, I have to say that the earnings quality is not trending in the right direction. As of Q3, 2025, PIK consumed ~7.5% of the total income, marking an increase of around 12% on a year-over-year basis (similar dynamic if we compare to the previous quarter). From this we can extract two takeaways:

  1. On a cash-basis, the current dividend is undercovered.
  2. It seems that the spread widening for new deals was to a some extent enabled by a change in underwriting standards (as evidenced by higher share of PIK income component in Q3 than in the previous quarter, and management's commentary on going into the LMM segment to search for higher spreads), which is, obviously, the right thing to do in order to combat the forthcoming pressures form lower base rates, but a risky game to play in the long-term.

The bottom line

ARCC is certainly a high-quality BDC and the Q3 data clearly support it.

Yet, in investing it is not only about value, but also about price you pay for it. While there is certainly a valid case for assuming premium pricing for ARCC, I still just don't see a justified ground for a) ~18% premium to sector median and b) similar gap from the likes of KBDC and MSDL.

When it comes to ARCC's total return performance for the next 12-month period, my assumption would be that there will be a NAV decline, which should motivate the market to either reprice the stock or at least price ARCC in a more negative fashion than, say, KBDC and MSDL (i.e., comparable BDCs with significant discounts). At the same time, I do not think that the the NAV drop would be as deep as we could imply from my aforementioned 8% to 10% income decline (even though there is no surplus after dividend distributions). We have to remember that ARCC has the ability to issue new equity at NAV and that it has a spare financial capacity to accommodate organic portfolio growth, which is inherently accretive provided that there are no non-accruals offsetting that.

Speaking of the dividend, in my humble opinion, ARCC's NII per share will continue to go down due to systematic headwinds - mostly lower base rates and continued spread compression. Again, I do not think that in the next 12-month period we will see 8% to 10% of a decline in the NII per share (as the pure math would suggest) and thus deeply under covered dividend because of the same exact reasons that I provided on the NAV component. Namely, ARCC has the ability to expand portfolio in an accretive manner and, on top of that, it has a notable undistributed spillover, which could be used for a long time.

So, the only scenario under which I could see ARCC cutting its dividend in the next 12-month period is if the pace and magnitude of base rate cuts accelerate (think of new Fed chair being a clear monetary dove) and there are new material non-accruals emerging (think of ARCC's PIK share and general weakness in the economy), which send the stock price below NAV and make the shortfall in the dividend coverage even deeper.

Finally, I think that ARCC is a hold. It is not a sell due to relatively balanced P/NAV (1.02x) and the potential that lies in the spare financial capacity that could come in handy for offsetting the pressures from lower base rates and new non-accruals, where the latter aspect has been historically well-managed by ARCC.

However, I do not think that ARCC is a buy either. Putting all of the aforementioned pieces together, I simply do not see how ARCC could deliver positive growth that would justify experiencing material NAV growth and thus share price increase. The decision to not invest in ARCC is for sure made easier by the fact that relatively comparable BDCs such as MSDL and KBDC trade at rather steep discount to ARCC (18% in KBDC's case and 19% in MSDL's case) - i.e., in a nutshell, ARCC's strengths are not sufficient to fully justify such a gap in the valuations.

data.title: Invesco EQV International Equity Fund Q3 2025 Commentary
data.description:
Manager perspective and outlook

  • Global equities delivered positive returns in the third quarter of 2025, supported by sustained apparent enthusiasm toward artificial intelligence (AI), central bank interest rate cuts and robust corporate earnings. In this environment, emerging market equities outperformed their developed market counterparts. Emerging market outperformance largely stemmed from Chinese equities, which benefited from easing of US trade tensions, growing optimism about AI-related developments and a weaker US dollar.
  • Among developed markets, US equities posted solid gains, bolstered by strong second quarter earnings. The US Federal Reserve’s first rate cut of the year, along with signals of further easing, also supported US stocks. Japanese equities advanced, aided by a new US trade agreement that reduced tariffs, ongoing corporate governance reforms and a resilient domestic economy. In contrast, German equities declined during the quarter, weighed down by a stagnating economy, weak manufacturing and exports, rising US trade tensions and heightened political uncertainty.
  • Our team remains focused on applying our long-term, bottom-up EQV investment process that seeks to identify attractively valued, high quality growth companies. We expect geopolitical and macroeconomic concerns to remain elevated, which has previously favored our conservative quality growth approach.

During the quarter, we initiated positions in the following stocks:

E Ink, a Taiwan-based information technology (IT) firm, is the sole provider of display tech for eReaders, eNotes and shelf labels, offering ultra-low power use and reduced eye strain. Retail adoption has been growing, and a shift to full-color and larger formats could improve profit margins. A recent stock correction due to macroeconomic concerns created an attractive entry point for us.

Bank Central Asia (BCA) Indonesia’s leading private bank, has continued to strengthen its deposit and loan franchise. Despite solid performance, macroeconomic and policy pressures led to a price decline that created for us a compelling entry point.

Airbus (OTCPK:EADSF)(OTCPK:EADSY), a European aerospace company, has been recovering from post-COVID supply chain issues, with production expected to normalize by early 2026. Its large order backlog, in our view, offers strong earnings visibility, while improving profit margins and defense spending growth add potential upside. We believe the stock’s underperformance versus its peers provided a timely opportunity.

We also bought China-based technology conglomerate Tencent (OTCPK:TCEHY), digital freight platform operator

Full Truck Alliance (YMM), e-commerce/technology company Alibaba (BABA) and industrials company Kanzhun (BZ), France-based building materials company CIE de Saint-Goban, British mining equipment company Weir (OTCPK:WEIGF) and Canada-based financials company Bank of Montreal (BMO) and aerospace manufacturer Bombardier (OTCQX:BDRAF)(OTCQX:BDRBF).

We sold several holdings:

Kingspan (OTCPK:KGSPF), an Irish building materials company, faced headwinds from weak construction activity and soft pricing. Despite what we see as strong leadership, a slower-than-expected recovery and premium valuation delayed realization of our thesis. We sold the position and reallocated to what we view as higher-quality EQV stocks, including Heidelberg (OTCPK:HLBZF) and Saint-Gobain (OTCPK:CODGF) that we believe are better positioned in favorable construction themes.

CGI, a Canadian IT services firm, has been in our view a solid long-term performer. However, weakening demand, AI-related disruption risks and pricing pressure raised concerns about its competitive advantage, prompting us to sell the stock.

Wolters Kluwer (OTCPK:WOLTF), a Dutch information services company, faced deteriorating earnings and slowing organic growth. The combination of AI risks, leadership transition and a premium valuation with limited downside protection led us to sell the stock.

We also sold British industrials company Ashtead (OTCPK:ASHTF) and three French companies – Edenred (OTC:EDNMF) in financials, Capgemini (OTCPK:CAPMF) in IT and Arkema (OTCPK:ARKAF)(OTCPK:ARKAY) in materials.

Fund holdings in healthcare outperformed those of the benchmark, contributing the most to relative return. Underweights in utilities and real estate also added to relative results. Geographically, exposure in the US (categorized by country of risk) and stock selection in Hong Kong and Australia contributed to relative return.

Stock selection in financials detracted the most from relative return, with notable weakness in financial exchanges. Holdings in consumer discretionary, materials and IT also underperformed their respective benchmark sectors, detracting from relative results. An underweight in materials hampered relative return as well. Geographically, stock selection in Japan, the UK and China were key detractors from relative results, as was an underweight in China.

Contributors to performance

Below are some of the largest contributors to absolute return for the quarter:

Taiwan Semiconductor beat second quarter earnings expectations and raised guidance. Strong AI chip demand, pricing power in advanced nodes and favorable foreign exchange trends boosted profit margins.

Legrand, a global specialist in electrical and digital building infrastructures, outperformed as revenue and margins beat expectations, supported by its data center “white space” business, which designs, builds and optimizes physical floor space of data centers. A recovery in real estate markets could further boost upside potential. Trip.com, China’s leading online travel agency, benefited from domestic travel growth and expanding international operations. Margins exceeded forecasts due to lower marketing spending.

Detractors from performance

Below are the largest detractors from absolute return for the quarter:

Shimano is a global leader in bike components. Profit margins fell short of expectations due to product rollout costs and overseas labor pressures. High bike inventories, especially in China, have remained a short-term drag, but we expect this to normalize over time.

RELX is a London-based provider of data analytics and decision tools (including Elsevier and LexisNexis). Potential disruption from AI, particularly in its Legal and Scientific, Technical and Medical (STM) segments, weighed on the stock’s valuation. Despite the company actively integrating AI into its offerings, apparent market skepticism and a high valuation prompted us to trim the position.

London Stock Exchange, a leading global market infrastructure and data provider, saw a decline in its stock price, driven by AI concerns about its Workspace and Refinitiv Eikon platforms, as well as rising competition. We believe the market currently undervalues its data/analytics business and its AI partnership with Microsoft (not a fund holding).

Expense ratios per the current prospectus: Class A: Net: 1.27%, Total: 1.27%; Class R6: Net: 0.86%, Total: 0.86%; Class Y: Net: 1.02%, Total: 1.02%.

Performance quoted is past performance and cannot guarantee comparable future results; current performance may be lower or higher. Visit invesco.com for the most recent month-end performance. Performance figures reflect reinvested distributions and changes in net asset value (NAV). Investment return and principal value will vary so that you

may have a gain or a loss when you sell shares. Returns less than one year are cumulative; all others are annualized. Index source: RIMES Technologies Corp. Had fees not been waived and/or expenses reimbursed in the past, returns would have been lower. Performance shown at NAV does not include the applicable front-end sales charge, which would have reduced the performance.

Class Y and R6 shares have no sales charge; therefore, performance is at NAV. Class Y shares are available only to certain investors. Class R6 shares are closed to most investors. Please see the prospectus for more details.

Investment objective

The fund seeks long-term growth of capital.

Fund facts

Fund AUM ($M) 2,244.59

Portfolio managers

Amrita Dukeshier, Brently Bates, Mark McDonnell, Michael Shaman, Richard Nield

About risk

Derivatives may be more volatile and less liquid than traditional investments and are subject to market, interest rate, credit, leverage, counterparty, and management risks. An investment in a derivative could lose more than the cash amount invested.

Environmental, Social and Governance (ESG) considerations may vary across investments and issuers, and not every ESG factor may be identified or evaluated for investment. The Fund will not be solely based on ESG considerations; therefore, issuers may not be considered ESG-focused companies. ESG factors may affect the Fund’s exposure to certain companies or industries and may not work as intended. The Fund may underperform other funds that do not assess ESG factors or that use a different methodology to identify and/or incorporate ESG factors. ESG is not a uniformly defined characteristic and as a result, information used by the Fund to evaluate such factors may not be readily available, complete or accurate, and may vary across providers and issuers. There is no guarantee that ESG considerations will enhance Fund performance.

The risks of investing in securities of foreign issuers can include fluctuations in foreign currencies, political and economic instability, and foreign taxation issues.

Growth stocks tend to be more sensitive to changes in their earnings and can be more volatile.

The Fund's value may be affected by changes in the stock markets. Stock markets may experience significant short-term volatility and may fall or rise sharply at times. Adverse events in any part of the equity or fixed-income markets may have unexpected negative effects on other market segments. Different stock markets may behave differently from each other and U.S. stock markets may move in the opposite direction from one or more foreign stock markets.

Stocks of medium-sized companies tend to be more vulnerable to adverse developments, may be more volatile, and may be illiquid or restricted as to resale.

The investment techniques and risk analysis used by the portfolio managers may not produce the desired results.

Preferred securities may include provisions that permit the issuer to defer or omit distributions for a certain period of time, and reporting the distribution for tax purposes may be required, even though the income may not have been received. Further, preferred securities may lose substantial value due to the omission or deferment of dividend payments.

The Fund is subject to certain other risks. Please see the current prospectus for more information regarding the risks associated with an investment in the Fund.

The opinions expressed are those of the fund’s portfolio management, are based on current market conditions and are subject to change without notice. These opinions may differ from those of other Invesco investment professionals.

This does not constitute a recommendation of any investment strategy or product for a particular investor. Investors should consult a financial professional before making any investment decisions.

Note: Not all products available at all firms. Financial professionals, please contact your home office.

The fund holdings are organized according to the Global Industry Classification Standard, which was developed by and is the exclusive property and service mark of MSCI Inc. and Standard & Poor’s.

* Alpha (cash adjusted) is a measure of performance on a risk-adjusted basis. Beta (cash adjusted) is a measure of relative risk and the slope of regression. Sharpe Ratio is a risk-adjusted measure calculated using standard deviation and excess return to determine reward per unit of risk. A higher Sharpe ratio indicates better risk-adjusted performance. Information Ratio is a measurement of portfolio returns beyond the returns of a benchmark, usually an index, compared to the volatility of those returns. Standard deviation measures a fund's range of total returns and identifies the spread of a fund's short-term fluctuations. Tracking Error is defined as the expected standard deviation of a portfolio's excess return over the benchmark index return. The up and down capture measures how well a manager was able to replicate or improve on periods of positive benchmark returns and how severely the manager was affected by periods of negative benchmark returns. Maximum Drawdown is the maximum observed loss from a high to a low of a portfolio, before a new high is attained. Maximum drawdown is an indicator of downside risk over a specified time period. Weighted Average Market Cap is a measure of the average size of company held in a portfolio. The percentage of the portfolio invested each company, or its weight, is multiplied by its size (market capitalization). An average of the weighted size of all companies held is then calculated. Price/earnings measures the price per share relative to the earnings per share of the company while excluding extraordinary items. Price to book measures the firm's capitalization (market price) to book value. Est. 3-5 year EPS (Earning per share) growth measures the earning per share growth from FY3 to FY5. ROE is the Return on Equity that measures the fund's annual return relative to total shareholders' equity. This ratio evaluates how quickly investments can be turned into profits. Long-term debt to capital measures a fund’s financial leverage by calculating the proportion of long-term debt used to finance its assets relative to the amount of equity used for the same purpose. A higher ratio indicates higher leverage. Operating margin measures the profit a fund makes for every dollar of sales after paying the variable expenses. Contribution to Return measures the performance impact from portfolio holdings over a defined time period. It takes into account both weight and performance of the portfolio holdings. Contribution to Return is calculated at security level.

Morningstar

It may not be copied or distributed and is not warranted to be accurate, complete or timely. Neither Morningstar nor its content providers are responsible for any damages or losses arising from any use of this information. Past performance is no guarantee of future results. data.title: Gildan Activewear: A Promising Yet Riskier Future, Including Hanesbrands
data.description:
Shares of Gildan Activewear (GIL) have been setting fresh highs in the aftermath of the announcement to purchase Hanesbrands (HBI).

That transformative deal was announced over the summer, having a huge impact on Gildan and while this likely has a positive impact and makes the company stronger, the company has some real execution and navigation to do post deal closing.

Integrated Activewear

Gildan is an activewear producer which claims that owning factories and controlling all the steps in the apparel production process is key to make great apparel. The company produces its own yarns, assemblage garments and distributes its own products.

Such vertical integration provides not just more opportunities to retain margins throughout the chain, but also helps with control and visibility, as the control also makes it easier for the business to implement key labor and environmental practices through its supply chain.

The company generates some 90% of sales from activewear products and the remainder from inner wear, with some 75% of sales tied to printer and just a 25% retail exposure. The company employs some 50,000 workers, is heavily focused on operations at ¨home¨ (that being Central America and the Caribbean), with almost all sales generated from in-house manufacturing.

The company generates some $3.3 billion in sales as a standalone business, these being very profitable operations, with EBITDA margins reported around 25% of sales. The company has seen modest operational advancements over the past decade, in which revenues rose some 30% to $3.3 billion, a period in which operating margins rose from the mid-teens to the low-twenties. By far the biggest achievement is that of capital allocation, with nearly 40% of the shares being bought back over this period of time.

Valuation Thoughts & Massive Deal

In July, the company reported its second quarter results, calling for 2025 sales growth up in the mid-single digits, seeing sales just over $3.4 billion this year. Operating margins are seen moving up towards 22% of sales, suggesting that a $750 million operating profit number might be in the works.

A $50 stock was granted a $7.5 billion equity valuation based on a share count of 149 million and some shares. Net debt of $1.8 billion resulted in a leverage ratio around 2.2 times, with the pro forma enterprise valuation pegged at $9.3 billion. That values the business at 2.7 times sales, around 11 times EBITDA and with adjusted earnings seen around $3.50 per share, equity was valued at a modest 14 times multiple on that front.

All this was about to change, as the company announced its intention to acquire troubled peer Hanesbrands in August, in order to create a leading global basic apparel leader. That deal valued Hanesbrands at $4.4 billion, split 50/50 between the valuation attached to the equity and net debt assumed.

The deal is designed to add the inner wear business of Hanesbrands, in order to create a much more balanced business with much larger scale, one with revenues seen more than doubling to $6.9 billion as Hanesbrands is even slightly larger in terms of sales. These scale benefits are key, with costs synergies seen reaching $200 million in year three post closing, that is equal to nearly 3% of pro forma sales!

Both businesses are pretty much different, with Hanesbrands focusing on inner wear, having more supply chains in Asia, which is a risk given the tariffs and being much stronger in retail instead of wholesale as well. The combination is set to employ over 90,000 workers with revenues split pretty evenly between active and inner wear as well as retail and wholesale outlets, having a more global exposure and certainly a more global supply chain.

Financial Impact

Deal terms call for largely an exchange of stock, with investors in Hanesbrands being given 0.102 shares of Gildan and $0.80 per share fore very share they own, valuing equity around $6.00 per share based on the unaffected share price.

Based on a share count of some 357 million shares, that implies little over 36 million shares of Gildan issued, with investors in HanesBrands´s given a 19.9% equity stake in the pro forma business with a share count of 185 million shares.

The cash component runs at less than $300 million, which in between existing net debt of $1.85 billion of Gildan and about $2.2 billion from Hanesbrands, makes for a roughly $4.4 billion net debt load. Pro forma EBITDA is seen at $1.35 billion, for a 3.2 times leverage ratio, as this leverage ratio falls to 2.8 times if we factor in the two hundred million in synergies.

The company sees leverage come down to 2.6 times, but this lower ratio is likely the result of timing of the deal closing, and the potential to deleverage until that point in time, as well as proceeds from the anticipated investment of the Hanesbrands activities in Australia.

If all this works, the company sees a 20% compounded annual growth rate in the period 2026 until 2028, that is from a $3.50 per share number seen this year, which at the lower end of the range suggests earnings per share of around $6 per share by 2028.

Investors Like It

Investors in Gildan, and thus Hanesbrands, acted relieved on the back of the deal announcement as shares rose some 10% to the $55 mark in August upon the announcement, having risen further to $60 in the weeks thereafter. This move is for good reasons, that of greater market position, more diversified operations abut moreover targeted synergies.

By the end of October, Gildan reported third quarter results, as the results triggered some minor both upward and downward revisions in the full year guidance here, with operating margins seen slightly higher than previously anticipated, while free cash flows are seen pressured a bit. Amidst the halt of buybacks until the acquisition, net debt was actually down over a hundred million (sequentially) to $1.74 billion. Further importance was the commentary on the Hanesbrands deal, already seen taking place later this year, or early in 2026, both being rather quick.

At the same time, expectations have risen a bit as well, given a quick 20% return in the time frame of just a few months since the deal for Hanesbrands has been announced. This is driven by anticipated earnings per share growth, but at the same time comes with leverage being on the increase, execution risks being apparent and synergies to be realized upon, with those cost savings being substantial by all means.

On paper there is much to like, driven by the significant synergies and earnings per share growth assumptions, however I have some reserves as well. This includes the fact that this is a Canadian-US acquisition, which is a bit more culturally sensitive these days. Moreover, with Hanesbrands losing its US status to some extent, more political risks related to tariffs might be on the increase again, after the situation has been highly uncertain already here.

In between all this, I am keen to watch the situation from here, but anticipating some hiccups down the road, I look forward to keeping a close eye on the business and are considering on potential and frankly anticipate hiccups here down the road.

data.title: Freeport-McMoRan: Grasberg Tragedy Will Pass
data.description:
Freeport-McMoRan Inc. (FCX) faces a difficult year ahead due to the tragic mud rush at the Grasberg mine in Indonesia. The copper miner faces much lower production over the next year, but the company should benefit from higher copper prices. My investment thesis remains Bullish on the stock, with the current price of Freeport-McMoRan not reflecting the price of copper over $5/lb.

Grasberg Tragedy

Back on September 8, the Grasberg Block Cave mine faced a mud rush, closing the copper and gold mine in Indonesia. Unfortunately, 7 team members were killed in the tragedy where ~800,000 metric tons of wet material entered the Grasberg Block Cave underground mine from the former Grasberg open pit and traveled rapidly to multiple levels of the mine.

Freeport-McMoRan reported Q3 results generally close to expectations, but the company expects major impacts to mining activities into 2026. The company is currently investigating the incident and working to remove the mud from the facilities through year end.

The copper miner submitted a plan back on September 24 to restart some unaffected areas during Q4, followed by a phased restart and ramp-up of the Grasberg Block Cave mine during 2026. Management is forecasting a reduction in 2026 production by ~35% of pre-incident estimates at 1.7 billion pounds of copper and 1.6 million ounces of gold.

Freeport-McMoRan plans to hold a conference call with analysts and investors on November 18 to update the market on the multi-year financial outlook in lieu of holding a Q3 '25 earnings call. The company would appear to suggest a full return to normal operations by 2027.

The key to the copper market is that the loss of 1.7 billion pounds of production will only contribute to much higher prices than otherwise. Copper currently trades near the all-time highs at $5.14/lb.

Morgan Stanley has recently predicted the most severe copper shortage in more than 20 years. The forecast is for over a 1 metric ton shortage to be reached by 2029.

As the below chart highlights, Freeport-McMoRan obtains over 600 million pounds of copper production from mines in the U.S. and South America not at risk here. Indonesia is the largest mining operation due to a combination of higher copper production than other regions, but also the massive amount of gold byproduct benefiting from record gold prices. The GBC accounts for 70% of forecasted production in Indonesia, with the other 30% potentially starting production in mid-Q4, providing roughly 700+ million pounds of production starting in 2026.

Minimal Impact To Q3

The September quarter was naturally hit by the Grasberg mine being closed for over 20 days. Freeport-McMoRan still reported higher revenues YoY for Q3 '25 due in part to higher realized prices for copper and gold.

The company reported Q3 '25 revenues of $7.0 billion, up $0.2 billion from last Q3. The company saw a big benefit where realized gold prices were up nearly $1,000/oz while copper sales volumes were only slightly below prior-year levels.

The consensus analyst estimates for 2027 haven't been modified much since the tragedy going on for nearly 2 months now. Analysts are predicting the following annual numbers:

  • EPS - $2.79
  • Revenue - $31.5 billion

Freeport-McMoRan lists a $3.0 billion cash balance with a debt level of $9.3 billion. The copper miner has a net debt level of $6.3 billion, placing the company in a strong position with the expectation for an insurance recovery of up to $1 billion.

The company faces a tough road ahead fully restarting GBC mining operations, but the business shouldn't see a major hit due to the higher copper prices from the lower output leading to a major copper shortage. Copper mines are difficult to develop, leaving a limited supply that can reach the market and replace the lost production.

The biggest risk is naturally a much longer period of ramping up production at Grasberg and even potentially some level of higher capex to get the GBC back operational with upwards of 300 million pounds of copper at risk. The company has a solid financial picture, and naturally any scenario where copper prices actually plunge in the next year would harm the business when most vulnerable.

Takeaway

The key investor takeaway is that Freeport-McMoRan has already rebounded from a mid-September update that caused a major selloff. Investors should use any future weakness in the stock to load up on the copper miner with signs 2027 capacity will return to normal and the copper market will face severe shortages. The company shouldn't face any long-term impacts from a mining incident, and investors should use market dislocations to add the copper miner.

data.title: XOP: Equal-Weighted E&P Beta - Hold For Now, Here Are The Triggers
data.description:
Introduction

XOP is an ETF for easy access to the “pure” beta of the exploration and production (E&P) segment in the US, with a modified equal-weight methodology that distributes the weight among dozens of companies (not just mega-caps) and a cost of 0.35%. With this philosophy XOP is more sensitive to the cycle and internal rotation of the sector, which historically brings with it greater volatility than a market-cap-weighted index, in exchange for better capturing the stretches of wide rises in the group.

Index-tracking quality is solid and the average performance difference is in line with costs. Currently the “problem” is not the vehicle, but the cycle that we will analyze later in the article.

Performance & Index Tracking

Total Return Review

As shown in the table, the quarterly cumulative NAV stands at +5.75% compared to 5.88% for the benchmark index. In addition, the annualized returns in its different time frames show a minimal difference versus market price, indicating that the creation/redemption mechanism (APs + market makers) minimizes premiums/discounts.

In addition, there are no surprises in the tracking difference of NAV returns versus index returns. The ranges are consistent with an expense ratio of 0.35% +/- the effect of income from the securities lending part, sampling and rebalancing costs of an “equal weighted” index (which involves a higher turnover vs a cap-weight and therefore higher costs).

As noted earlier, NAV and market price have been in near-perfect alignment: they coincide in the 1 and 10 year tranches, while they barely differ in 1-2 bp in 3 and 5 years. Therefore, the price of the market share correctly reflects the value of the underlying basket and suggests that average discounts/premiums are low with good market depth.

Finally, XOP has a modest 30D yield of 2.49% that adds to the position of investors and reinforces the thesis of the fund proposal based on the exposure to the beta of the E&P segment and not maximize coupons/dividends.

Friendly reminder: this is a cyclical sector

The difference between 5Y and 10Y returns is 26.76 p.p. annualized that we observe in the data in the table, are due to the “super-cycle” that the energy sector lived in the post-pandemic era (2020), which recalls the high cyclicality of E&P that entails very profitable expansion periods and long phases of contraction that compensate (in the opposite sense) for the composite performance of the decade. In addition, the 2.49% yield that we have commented also depends a lot on the cycle and usually has variations depending on what is the current time of the E&P.

Tracking error

Taking as reference the annualized values (1/3/5/10 years), we estimate an annual tracking difference of -0.33 bps (approx.) annually. Typically, for a passively managed ETF such as XOP, the fund is expected to maintain a distance from the index at an amount similar to the cost. The -0.33p.p. average fits with the expense ratio of 0.35%.

In the image above, we see the tracking error of +4.78 bps (12-month window, as of Sep 30, 2025). Therefore, the monthly dispersion between XOP (NAV) vs the index has been minimal and the good management of the vehicle is confirmed, which accurately replicates the mechanics of the S&P Oil & Gas E&P Select Industry.

Ultimately, the outcome of the position against the index will depend mainly on the expense ratio and the timing of rebalances.

Risk: Volatility and Drawdowns

Using daily adjusted closing prices (Yahoo Finance), we compute 3-year, 90-day and 30-day annualized volatility.

The ETF’s 3-year historical volatility remains elevated, which is consistent with the equal-weight profile as well as with the characteristic of cyclical assets with profitable upswings followed by deep corrections.

On the other hand, the 90d signal serves us very well to reflect the action of recent quarters and we compare it with the 30d signal to observe shocks in the short term. Thus, when 30-day volatility stays above 90-day volatility as is the recent case, it indicates a recent moment of tension with respect to the quarter. With 30-day (0.30) > 90-day (0.25) and slightly above 3-year (0.29), the implied move is ~1.9%–1.6% per day (0.30/√252 to 0.25/√252)

Although the maximum drawdown is 89% , this occurred during COVID, under normal conditions corrections could be expected from ATH in the range of 40%-60% and reminds us of the cyclicality of the sector, in which the price of the dollar and financing conditions play a determining role. Although we do not know what will happen in the future, it can guide us to understand the % of losses that the investor can face.

From a max-drawdown (MDD) perspective and with recently expanding volatility, the idea is to maintain prudence and size the position and even reduce the size by 20-30% (approx. the ratio 30d-90d : 1.2) by taking advantage of the high 30d and improving the outflow results. Similarly, we would go back on the offensive when the volatility at 30d gave way to the quarterly and at the same time the quarterly also stopped rising.

XOP vs others: IEO & FCG

Today, the relative volatility reading suggests that XOP offers more beta than IEO, useful if you're looking for breadth, but requires adjusting size to risk, scaling inflows, and incorporating risk limits/stop-loss bands. With respect to FCG, the weight of the gas is what makes the differences, when it commands the ETF usually shows greater volatility with better periods of profitability.

Portfolio & Exposure

The Top 10 holdings are another example of the equal-weight philosophy in which each holding is between 2.6%-2.9%. In this group, oil E&P (Diamondback Energy, Murphy Oil, Expand Energy), gas-tilt E&P (EQT, Range Resources, CNX Resources) and refining/marketing (Valero, Marathon Petroleum, HF Sinclair) coexist. Also, refiners appear even though they are not conceptually from the E&P sector due to the index methodology, which includes Refining & Marketing constituents.

The fund page shows the allocation by sub-industry: 70% E&P, 22% Refining & Marketing and 8% Integrated. This “pie” is relevant to understanding the ETF’s beta: it concentrates the bulk in E&P, but the 22% allocated to Refining & Marketing is considerable enough to cushion the blow when crack spreads widen as crude prices fall, helping cushion upstream weakness.

Similarly, XOP has 52 securities and by not concentrating on 2-3 giants, it reduces concentration risk per issuer but in return, the total volatility of the ETF may be higher than in a comparable cap-weight. That is, as long as E&P is doing well, the amplitude adds up, and on the contrary, the whole suffers.

Analysis - Macro Fundamental

Physical Tightness Composite

The Physical Tightness Composite series summarizes in a single weekly index the state of the energy market combining prices with physical-market tightness. It is built with three pieces in z-score:

  • z_WTI : The price of standardized WTI crude oil in z-score over a moving window (weekly).

  • z_HH: Henry Hub gas price standardized in z-score (weekly).

  • z_Inv_inv: U.S. commercial crude oil inventories inverted and standardized; measures tightness. It is inverted because less inventory implies a tighter market and is a positive reading, thus aligning the logic of the movement with the other series.

The formula for obtaining the Physical Tightness Composite applies a weight of 60% to prices (giving more importance to crude than to gas in a ratio of 70-30) and 40% to the physical stress (low inventories). This gives the formula: Physical Tightness Composite = 0.6*(0.7*z_WTI + 0.3*z_HH) + 0.4*z_Inv_inv.

To interpret it, when the series is above 0 is a positive indicator that can be given by prices above their recent averages and/or contained inventories. Meanwhile, when it is below zero the context is unfavorable.

As a rule, since a z-score measures how many standard deviations a variable is from its recent average, stretches above +0.5 are not considered “one-week noise” and anticipate tailwinds. I would apply the opposite in -0.5.

Financial Conditions Composite

For the other part of the macro analysis, we will use the Financial Conditions Composite. This signal brings together in a single weekly index three legs that influence the valuation and financing of E&P:

  • z_HY_inv: spread high yield (HY OAS) in inverted z-score. Because the lower the credit, the better, it is reversed to match the logic.

  • z_Real_inv: real rate 10Y (DFII10) in inverted z-score; reversed by the same case: low real rates → best discount.

  • z_USD_inv: Broad U.S. Dollar Index (DTWEXBGS) in inverted z-score. It is also reversed because a weak (LOW) USD is positive for refinancing other economies and is beneficial for commodities (DTWEXBGS is used against DXY because it better represents the “global” USD that affects oil demand and price formation).

In this case, the signal is composed of a weighted average in which greater weight is given to the credit leg (z_HY_inv): 50%, followed by z_Real_inv with 30% and finally, 20% for z_USD_inv. Thus, the formula we use is: Financial Conditions Composite = 0.5*z_HY_inv + 0.3*z_Real_inv + 0.2 * z_USD_inv.

To analyze it, values above 0 suggest a favorable financial environment that can be given by contained spreads, lower real rates and/or a less strong USD. Below zero, we would be in an unfavorable environment. Likewise, the logic would be applied that when the composite is in a stretch above +0.5 , we would speak of tailwinds for the E&P and vice versa when the value is < -0.5. Close to its historical average (zero), we would treat it as a neutral regime, in which case it is better to wait for movements to either side to draw conclusions.

Physical Tightness Composite Zoom

Analyzing both composites, after two attacks of Physical Tightness to break the rise first in January and June this year, failed to consolidate momentum and since then the trend has been downward, recently standing at -0.60. This is a sign of an unfavorable environment, in which the clearly determining factor is a below-normal price of oil. A rebound in the price of crude oil, news of a decline in production, or a further narrowing of inventories, would help reverse the trend. However, financial conditions are shown to be in a positive zone of +0.69. So for the time being, neither real rates nor the strength of the dollar are holding back the sector's prices.

With the physical backdrop against us and financial conditions supportive, the situation is prudent as a worsening of financial conditions would add to the negative effect of the physicist. Meanwhile, the baseline scenario for 3-6 months suggests that we will see a range with lateral-bearish bias for XOP, limited by the lack of physical support. Based on this, the suggested operation is to maintain the position and avoid adding / scaling in until we see an improvement of the Physical Tightness is seen. In the event that financial conditions change course and do not change the pattern of Physical Tightness, consider reducing positions.

Conclusion

Finally, our XOP ETF offers pure beta to the E&P with equal weighting but at the same time brings greater volatility against cap-weighted alternatives.

Likewise, until a clear catalyst to boost oil and gas prices emerges, even with financial conditions in a favorable environment, the recommended stance is Hold.

Thank you for your reading.

data.title: Graphite Miners News For The Month Of October 2025
data.description:
Welcome to the October edition of the graphite miners news.

The past month saw China battery related flake graphite spot prices generally flat.

Graphite price news

During the past 30 days the China graphite flake-194 EXW spot price was down 0.81%. The China graphite flake +195 EXW spot price was flat. Note that 94-97% is considered best suited for use in batteries; it is then upgraded to 99.9% purity to make “spherical” graphite used in Li-ion batteries. The spherical graphite 99.95% min EXW China price was flat the past 30 days. Note: Graphite electrode prices were flat.

Note: SMM lists the current flake-194 graphite spot price at US$365/t including VAT, roughly flat from US$369 last month.

Graphite demand and supply forecast charts

The IEA Global critical Minerals Outlook 2024 report forecasts graphite demand and supply pipeline to 2040 (source)

Trend Investing v IEA demand forecast for EV metals (IEA)

2021 IEA forecast growth in demand for selected minerals from clean energy technologies by scenario, 2040 relative to 2020 - Increases Of Lithium 13x to 42x, Graphite 8x to 25x, Cobalt 6x to 21x, Nickel 7x to 19x, Manganese 3x to 8x, Rare Earths 3x to 7x, And Copper 2x to 3x

Graphite market news

On October 7 Yahoo Finance reported:

Global Graphite Market 2026-2036: Graphite demand is projected to rise 310% by 2036, with battery anodes growing from 28% of consumption in 2024 to 62% by 2036.

On October 9 Global Times reported:

China announces export controls on lithium batteries, graphite anode materials...introducing export controls on specific lithium battery and graphite anode material items, effective November 8, 2025... Additionally, technologies used in producing these controlled lithium-ion battery items are subject to the new restriction...Exporters of these items are required to apply for permits from the competent authorities at the Ministry of Commerce...

Note: See below news in late October where US and China have worked out a framework for a trade deal.

On October 12 Market Screener reported: "AMG Critical Materials exits natural graphite business in $65 million deal for Graphit Kropfmühl."

On October 21 ABC News reported:

Donald Trump says critical minerals deal with Australia will produce 'so much' in race against China...The US-AU Critical Minerals Framework is expected to begin investing in about a dozen projects necessary for producing weapons, electronics and renewables...Altogether the Australian and US governments intend to spend $US3 billion ($4.6 billion) in the next six months to make "immediate" investments in a pipeline of critical minerals projects in nearly every state and territory in Australia... [it] isn't just digging things up, it's also about processing...In exchange for the financing, the Australian and US governments will be able to take a stake in the ownership of those facilities, and be granted a "right of offtake", essentially guaranteeing some of the supply from those facilities will be available to Australia and the US...A separate critical minerals "strategic reserve" could remove some risk for investors by setting a floor price on "priority" minerals. It is not due to come into effect until the end of next year. A government task force is considering potential price support mechanisms and what minerals will be supported...Some of these projects could completely reshape supply. The Queensland graphite mine, for example, is home to the world's third-largest deposit of graphite.

On October 26 CNBC reported:

U.S. and China talks sketch out rare earths, tariff pause for Trump and Xi to consider...Top Chinese and U.S. economic officials on Sunday hashed out the framework of a trade deal for U.S. President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping to decide on later this week.

Ltd. [SHE:001301], and Zhongke [SHE:300035]).

September 2025 Quarterly Activities and Cashflow Report.

  • 24kt natural graphite sold and shipped to third-party customers at US$625 per tonne (CIF)1 weighted average price.

On October 1 NextSource Materials announced:

Positive results of Technical & Economic Study for proposed Battery Anode Facility in the UAE and secures industrial site with building in Abu Dhabi.

  • Study confirms total UAE BAF production capacity of 30,000 tonnes per annum (“tpa”) of anode active material (“AAM”), satisfying production demands of existing Mitsubishi Chemical offtake agreement and accommodating future demand growth from new offtake agreements.

  • Average annual forecasted revenues of US$195 million and annual EBITDA of US$76 million, at full production.
  • Initial production planned for Q4 2026 with full production rate achieved in early 2028.
  • Strategic partner process launched: discussions underway with offtake partners and several global debt and equity investors.

Conclusion

October saw China battery related flake graphite spot prices roughly flat.

Highlights for the month were:

  • Graphite demand is projected to rise 310% by 2036, with battery anodes growing from 28% of consumption in 2024 to 62% by 2036.
  • China announces export controls on specific lithium battery and graphite anode material items, effective November 8, 2025. (Note: An imminent trade deal may likely change this)
  • Donald Trump says critical minerals deal with Australia will produce 'so much' in race against China. A separate critical minerals "strategic reserve" could remove some risk for investors by setting a floor price on "priority" minerals.
  • U.S. and China talks sketch out rare earths, tariff pause for Trump and Xi to consider.
  • Syrah Resources Sept. 2025 quarter - 26kt natural graphite production at Balama, 24kt natural graphite sold.

  • Renascor Resources PSG demonstration plant on schedule for commencement of on-site commissioning this quarter.
  • Talga Group awarded SEK 82.6 million (A$13.3m) grant from Swedish government, advances near-term Talga graphite anode production.
  • Falcon Energy Materials - Morocco CSPG Pilot Plant set for Q4 2025 completion.

  • International Graphite continues to achieve key milestones in the development of Australia’s first commercial graphite micronising facility at Collie, WA.
  • Zentek subsidiary Albany Graphite Corp. provides additional positive nuclear suitability testing results.

As usual all comments are welcome.

data.title: Aristotle International Equity ADR WM Composite: Q3 2025 Contributors And Detractors
data.description:
The following segment was excerpted from the Aristotle International Equity ADR WM Q3 2025 Commentary

Relative Contributors Relative Detractors
ING Groep (ING) MonotaRO (MONOY, MONOF)
Credicorp (BAP) Accenture (ACN)
Cameco (CCJ) DSM-Firmenich (OTC:KDSKF)
Sony (SONY) Alcon (ALC)
Erste Group (OTCPK:EBKOF)(OTCPK:EBKDY) Bank Haleon (HLN)

MonotaRO, the Japanese business-to-business (B2B) e-commerce platform, was the largest detractor during the quarter. The company—which enables customers to source millions of maintenance, repair and operations (MRO) products through a centralized digital interface—reported a deceleration in sales growth, prompting downward revisions to full-year targets. Results were impacted by weaker-than-expected demand from industrial end markets, and we believe some of the share price weakness also reflected profit-taking following strong performance in prior periods. From our perspective, these short-term dynamics do not alter the structural advantages of MonotaRO’s business model. The company continues to gain traction with large enterprise customers, who now represent over 30% of sales. These clients typically have higher lifetime value and are more likely to adopt MonotaRO’s value-added services, such as purchase management systems, which enhance customer retention and deepen relationships. Importantly, we believe MonotaRO’s value proposition lies in convenience, execution and product curation—qualities that are difficult to replicate in Japan’s fragmented MRO market. With a high-margin, asset-light model, a scalable platform and a long runway to expand share across businesses of all sizes, we continue to view MonotaRO as a high-quality, competitively advantaged business.

Accenture, the global IT consultancy, was one of the largest detractors. The company’s operations are split roughly evenly between Consulting and Managed Services (outsourcing). While Accenture’s strategic pivot to AI in 2023 has driven a rapid increase in AI-related revenue and bookings (nearly doubling to $5.9 billion in fiscal 2025), investors have grown increasingly concerned about the longer-term impact of AI on its outsourcing business—revenue heavily reliant on billable hours. Moreover, the U.S. government’s DOGE initiative created a headwind, as federal contracts have historically represented about 8% of Accenture’s revenue. Despite these challenges, Accenture continues to grow, albeit at a below-normal rate in the recent period, while simultaneously investing in its workforce—now employing roughly 77,000 AI and data specialists, about 10% of its global staff—and returning billions of dollars to shareholders through double-digit increases in both dividends (+10% year-over-year) and share buybacks (+15%). While we acknowledge that market concerns about AI’s disruptive potential warrant consideration, we believe Accenture shares have been excessively punished (valuations are at 10-year lows). The stock has retreated to mid-2020 levels, even though earnings per share and FREE cash flow are more than 50% and 40% higher, respectively, than they were at that time.

Credicorp, the largest bank in Peru, was a leading contributor during the quarter. Results exceeded expectations, supported by robust loan growth—particularly in microfinance and retail segments—stable asset quality and disciplined cost management, even as Peru’s central bank cut rates. From our perspective, these outcomes represent the strength of a well-executed long-term strategy. Credicorp’s multi-pronged platform—anchored in banking, insurance and wealth management—offers durable advantages in an underpenetrated financial system. Its leading positions in microfinance (via Mibanco), pension fund management and investment advisory foster lasting customer relationships and recurring revenue through multi-product engagement. The company is also prudently expanding its digital ecosystem, enhancing efficiency and broadening access across income levels. Importantly, even amid macroeconomic uncertainty, management has consistently prioritized long-term value over volume, allocating capital conservatively and maintaining disciplined underwriting. We believe this enduring combination of diversification, market leadership and risk-aware culture supports our conviction in Credicorp as a resilient business with the ability to compound value over time.

Erste Group Bank (OTCPK:EBKOF), a leading retail and commercial bank in Central and Eastern Europe, was a primary contributor during the quarter. Shares rose following strong results, supported by healthy loan growth, stable deposits and solid fee income. Looking beyond near-term performance, Erste announced its intent to acquire a significant stake in Santander Bank Polska (OTCPK:BKZHF), one of Poland’s largest banks. This transaction would expand Erste’s geographic footprint into a structurally attractive market, adding scale and diversification while providing exposure to one of the fastest-growing economies in the region. As a retail-oriented bank with meaningful exposure to underbanked populations across Central and Eastern Europe, we believe Erste is well positioned to benefit as Central and Eastern economies grow, cross key income thresholds, and drive increasing demand for financial services. In addition, we believe ongoing cost efficiencies—particularly through increased use of technology—should further improve profitability.

(All MSCI index returns are shown net and in U.S. dollars unless otherwise noted.)

Disclosures

The opinions expressed herein are those of Aristotle Capital Management, LLC (Aristotle Capital) and are subject to change without notice. Past performance is not a guarantee or indicator of future results. This material is not financial advice or an offer to buy or sell any product. You should not assume that any of the securities transactions, sectors or holdings discussed in this report were or will be profitable, or that recommendations Aristotle Capital makes in the future will be profitable or equal the performance of the securities listed in this report. The portfolio characteristics shown relate to the Aristotle International Equity ADR strategy. Not every client’s account will have these characteristics. Aristotle Capital reserves the right to modify its current investment strategies and techniques based on changing market dynamics or client needs. There is no assurance that any securities discussed herein will remain in an account’s portfolio at the time you receive this report or that securities sold have not been repurchased. The securities discussed may not represent an account’s entire portfolio and, in the aggregate, may represent only a small percentage of an account’s portfolio holdings. The performance attribution presented is of a representative account from Aristotle Capital’s International Equity ADR strategy. The representative account is a discretionary client account which was chosen to most closely reflect the investment style of the strategy. The criteria used for representative account selection is based on the account’s period of time under management and its similarity of holdings in relation to the strategy. Recommendations made in the last 12 months are available upon request.

Composite returns are presented pure gross and net of the maximum wrap fee and include the reinvestment of all income. Pure gross returns do not reflect the deduction of any trading costs or other fees and are supplemental to the net returns. Net returns are calculated by subtracting the highest applicable wrap/SMA fee, which includes trading costs and custodial fees, from the pure gross composite return. (From inception to 12/31/2015, the highest applicable wrap/SMA fee is 3.00% on an annual basis, or 0.75% quarterly. From 1/1/2016 to 12/31/2023, the highest applicable wrap/SMA fee is 2.00% on an annual basis, or 0.50% quarterly and 0.17% monthly from 1/1/2024 to present.)

Performance Disclosures

Sources: CAPS CompositeHubTM, MSCI

Composite returns for all periods ended September 30, 2025 are preliminary pending final account reconciliation.

Past performance is not indicative of future results. The information provided should not be considered financial advice or a recommendation to purchase or sell any particular security or product. Performance results for periods greater than one year have been annualized.

Pure gross returns do not reflect the deduction of any trading costs or other fees and are supplemental to the net returns. Net returns are calculated by subtracting the highest applicable wrap/SMA fee, which includes trading costs and custodial fees, from the pure gross composite return. (From inception to 12/31/2015, the highest applicable wrap/SMA fee is 3.00% on an annual basis, or 0.75% quarterly. From 1/1/2016 to 12/31/2023, the highest applicable wrap/SMA fee is 2.00% on an annual basis, or 0.50% quarterly and 0.17% monthly from 1/1/2024 to present.)

Index Disclosures

The MSCI EAFE Index (Europe, Australasia, Far East) is a free float-adjusted market capitalization-weighted index that is designed to measure the equity market performance of developed markets, excluding the United States and Canada. The MSCI EAFE Index consists of the following 21 developed market country indexes: Australia, Austria, Belgium, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Hong Kong, Ireland, Israel, Italy, Japan, the Netherlands, New Zealand, Norway, Portugal, Singapore, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland and the United Kingdom. The MSCI ACWI captures large and mid-cap representation across 23 developed market countries and 24 emerging markets countries. With approximately 2,500 constituents, the Index covers approximately 85% of the global investable equity opportunity set. The MSCI ACWI Growth Index captures large and mid-cap securities exhibiting overall growth style characteristics across 23 developed markets countries and 24 emerging markets countries. The MSCI ACWI Value Index captures large and mid-cap securities exhibiting overall value style characteristics across 23 developed markets countries and 24 emerging markets countries. The MSCI ACWI ex USA Index captures large and mid-cap representation across 22 of 23 developed markets countries (excluding the United States) and 24 emerging markets countries. With approximately 2,000 constituents, the Index covers approximately 85% of the global equity opportunity set outside the United States. The MSCI Emerging Markets Index is a free float-adjusted market capitalization-weighted index that is designed to measure the equity market performance of emerging markets. The MSCI Emerging Markets Index consists of the following 24 emerging market country indexes: Brazil, Chile, China, Colombia, Czech Republic, Egypt, Greece, Hungary, India, Indonesia, Korea, Kuwait, Malaysia, Mexico, Peru, Philippines, Poland, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, South Africa, Taiwan, Thailand, Turkey and United Arab Emirates. The S&P 500 ((SP500), (SPX))® Index is the Standard & Poor’s Composite Index of 500 stocks and is a widely recognized, unmanaged index of common stock prices. The Brent Crude Oil Index is a major trading classification of sweet light crude oil that serves as a major benchmark price for purchases of oil worldwide. The MSCI Japan Index is designed to measure the performance of the large and mid-cap segments of the Japanese market. With approximately 200 constituents, the Index covers approximately 85% of the free float-adjusted market capitalization in Japan. The Bloomberg Global Aggregate Bond Index is a flagship measure of global investment grade debt from 27 local currency markets. This multi-currency benchmark includes treasury, government-related, corporate and securitized fixed-rate bonds from both developed and emerging markets issuers. The MSCI United Kingdom Index is designed to measure the performance of the large and mid-cap segments of the U.K. market. With nearly 100 constituents, the Index covers approximately 85% of the free float-adjusted market capitalization in the United Kingdom. The MSCI Europe Index captures large and mid-cap representation across 15 developed markets countries in Europe. With approximately 400 constituents, the Index covers approximately 85% of the free float-adjusted market capitalization across the European developed markets equity universe. UK CPI Index is a measurement of inflation and prices, including consumer price inflation, producer price inflation and the House Price Index. These indexes have been selected as the benchmarks and are used for comparison purposes only. The volatility (BETA) of the Composite may be greater or less than the respective benchmarks.
